[[Ringgold, Louisiana]], [[United States]] | death_date = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Texas blues]], [[electric blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1950s–present | label = [[Alligator Records|Alligator]], various | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Long John Hunter''' (born July 13, 1931) is an [[United States|American]] [[Texas blues]] and [[electric blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter.{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/long-john-hunter-mn0000826917/biography |title=Long John Hunter | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} He has released seven albums in his own name, and in his later years found critical acknowledgement outside of his homeland. Hunter's best known tracks are "El Paso Rock" and "Alligators Around My Door", the latter of which Hunter co-wrote with [[Bruce Iglauer]]. ==Life and career== '''John Thurman Hunter Jr.''' was born in [[Ringgold, Louisiana]], [[United States]].{{cite web |url=http://www.centrohd.com/bio/bio21/long_john_hunter_b.htm |title=Long John Hunter |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Centrohd.com |accessdate=September 13, 2011}} He was raised on a farm in [[Magnolia, Arkansas]], but by his early twenties was working in a box factory in [[Beaumont, Texas]]. He bought his first guitar after attending a [[B. B. King]] concert, and then adopted the [[stage name]] of Long John Hunter in 1953. Hunter saw his first [[Single (music)|single]], "She Used to Be My Woman" b/w "Crazy Girl", released by [[Duke Records]] in 1953. By 1957 he had relocated to [[El Paso, Texas]], and found employment playing at the Lobby Club in [[Ciudad Juárez|Juárez]], [[Mexico]]. He remained there for over thirteen years, seeing the release of several singles in the early 1960s on local [[record label]]s. These tracks included one of his most notable numbers, "El Paso Rock". In 1988, his [[album]], ''Texas Border Town Blues'' was released. In 1992, ''Ride with Me'' preceded a couple more albums for [[Alligator Records]], ''Border Town Legend'' (1996) and ''Swinging from the Rafters'' (1997). In 1999, Hunter teamed up with [[Lonnie Brooks]] and [[Phillip Walker]] to release ''Lone Star Shootout''.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/lone-star-shootout-mw0000244443/credits |title=Lone Star Shootout - Lonnie Brooks | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=1999-05-25 |accessdate=2014-01-27}} Hunter appeared at the [[Long Beach Blues Festival]] in both 1996 and 2000. His most recent album release was ''Looking for a Party'' (2009). ==Discography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
